data.home_page_mcc: Through problem definition training, increasing connectivity within and between communities, and driving towards implementation, the Multi City Challenge enables committed cities to collectively tackle problems they have been unable to solve on their own.
data.about_govlab: The Governance Lab’s (The GovLab) mission is to improve people’s lives by changing the way we govern. Our goal at The GovLab is to strengthen the ability of institutions — including but not limited to governments — and people to work more openly, collaboratively, effectively, and legitimately to make better decisions and solve public problems. We believe that increased availability and use of data, new ways to leverage the capacity, intelligence, and expertise of people in the problem-solving process, combined with new advances in technology and science, can transform governance. We approach each challenge and opportunity in an interdisciplinary, collaborative way, irrespective of the problem, sector, geography, and level of government. For more information, visit https://www.thegovlab.org.
data.about_undp: UNDP is the leading United Nations organisation fighting to end the injustice of poverty, inequality, and climate change. Working with our broad network of experts and partners in 170 countries, we help nations to build integrated, lasting solutions for people and planet.
data.intro_text: City governments do not need to look far to find expertise. Their own civil servants and communities are best positioned to identify where public services fall short and possess the specialised knowledge needed to solve complex public challenges.
data.about_mcc:
Africa’s urban population will triple to over 1.3 billion people by 2050 – so inclusive and sustainable cities are a priority. The United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Global Centre for Technology, Innovation, and Sustainable Development and The Governance Lab (The GovLab) at New York University Tandon School of Engineering are proud to announce their collaboration with five African cities to launch the 2020 Multi-City Challenge Africa public engagement initiative.

The Multi-City Challenge combines extensive training for public servants to learn how to engage with residents (citizen engagement), with a competition to invite the public to share solutions (collective intelligence) and then a coaching programme for residents and public services to develop those solutions into implementable new policies and services. The initiative aims to tackle pressing urban challenges by partnering with the people most affected by these issues – city residents.

 Residents in Accra (Ghana), Bahir Dar (Ethiopia), Kampala (Uganda), Kano (Nigeria), and Mutare (Zimbabwe) will be invited to develop solutions to three problems the cities are collectively confronting: digitalising the informal economy, building urban resilience, and improving waste management. Public servants will participate in an extensive training curriculum beginning this week focusing on problem definition to define the challenges precisely and with the benefit of data and citizen input. They will then launch an open innovation challenge toward the end of 2020 where city residents submit innovative ideas for how to best solve these priority issues.

The Multi-City Challenge Africa builds on successful implementation of the City and Multi-City Challenge model in Latin America, the US, and Europe. African city leaders will have the opportunity to work with other cities, pooling the expertise from their communities in this first-of-its-kind public engagement effort across cities. This initiative will also be advised by a group of experts on citizen engagement in Africa that will constitute the advisory board for the project.
data.about_undp_gct: The Global Centre for Technology, Innovation and Sustainable Development is a joint initiative by the Government of Singapore and UNDP which aims at identifying and co-creating technological solutions for sustainable development. The Centre curates partnerships, identifies solutions and connects partners and innovations with UNDP’s Global Policy Network and development partners.
data.terms:
Participation and use of the platform

  • Anyone who wishes to participate must register online and must accept the terms and conditions.
  • The GovLab reserves the right to modify these conditions, the latest version of which will be published on this website.
  • Any person over the age of 18 who has previously registered on the open challenge portal (Your Priorities) can participate. By accepting these terms of use, you declare that you are 18 years or older. 
  • The YourPriorities platform is a space to share and evaluate ideas related to challenges presented by the participating cities; users are obliged to use it diligently and in accordance with this objective.
  • The GovLab is not responsible for the incorrect use of the platform by users or the content located thereon. Each user is responsible for its correct use and the legality of the content and opinions they have shared. 
  • The GovLab reserves the right to limit access to the platform, including content and user comments, and to install filters for this purpose.
  • The use of the platform for purposes other than sharing and evaluating ideas is prohibited.
  • In the event of a violation of the acceptable use of the platform, The GovLab reserves the right to temporarily suspend the activity of a participant, disable their account and/or delete their content, without prejudice to other responsibilities that may be claimed.
  • In the event that the content entered by users incorporates a link to another website, The GovLab will not be responsible for damages or losses arising from access to the link or its contents.
  • In the event of litigation of any kind or for any reason between the participants on the website and / or a third party, The GovLab will be exempt from any liability claims, demands or damages of any nature related to or derived from the litigation.
  • There is no cost to participate in the program.
  • The personal data provided by users who register on the platform will only be used to manage the participatory process and statistical analysis of participation. The GovLab is solely responsible for the management of the data. A participant may request the rectification of their data or cancellation of the participation at any time (contact multicitychallenge@thegovlab.org)

Ideas

  • At the time of sending the idea, the participant certifies that they have read and understood the terms and conditions and their eligibility for participating.
  • The participant will declare and guarantee, when presenting their idea, that the ideas are their own and that they are the sole and exclusive owner of the rights.
  • The participant must own the authorship of the proposed solution, as well as the images used for the production of the participation video and any other audiovisual or printed material included as part of the application, exonerating the Multi-City Challenge Team for any error in authorship acknowledgments.
  • The participant declares to know and accept the fact that the information provided on the platform may be published on the websites of the Multi-City Challenge Africa and The GovLab, as well as through other means that The GovLab deems appropriate to promote the program.
  • The GovLab will process requests for removal of content that violate the terms of use. The GovLab reserves the right to make the appropriate checks or verifications prior to the removal of any content.
  • The result of the selected winners will be the responsibility of the panel who will evaluate the ideas and is final.
  • The participants of the selected ideas will not receive remuneration or compensation from the cities or The GovLab for the development of the ideas. Participation is a voluntary commitment of each participant.

For any questions please email multicitychallenge@thegovlab.org
data.how_to_participate:
PROGRAMME GOAL

The Multi-City Challenge Africa aims to solve complex urban problems in collaboration with the people most affected by these problems: the residents of the city. The programme offers training to public officials of the participating cities to support them in defining challenges and solving them in collaboration with their residents. It offers the community a space to participate in the design and formulation of public policies and programmes at the local level, allowing them to provide their innovative ideas to overcome these challenges.

THE CHALLENGES

The participating cities, Accra, Bahir Dar, Kampala, Kano, and Mutare, have defined three shared challenges to solve together with their communities. 

  • Reducing waste generation and improving waste management - Accra, Bahir Dar, and Kano. 
  • Building urban resilience in slums and informal settlements - Accra, Kampala, Kano, and Mutare.
  • Integrating the informal economy - Accra, Kampala, and Mutare.

WHAT IS A GOOD IDEA?

We seek innovative, low-cost ideas to solve these challenges that can be implemented by the cities in the short term. Solutions can include products, services, software, methods, models, public programme designs, and more. Solutions do not need to be novel. In fact, something that is in use elsewhere is of great interest but must be supported by evidence that the proposed solution will work in one of the participating cities.

WHY PARTICIPATE

Winners of the challenge will receive a recognition from New York University. Besides that, they will get the chance to sit-down with UNDP, The Governance Lab, and the participating city councils to study how to implement their idea into a pilot that can be scaled!

WHO CAN PARTICIPATE?

Individuals or organisations interested in working to improve the urban context of the participating cities and, therefore, the quality of life of the residents, can participate regardless of their place of residence. However, we especially invite the residents of the five participating cities to submit ideas and to evaluate solutions proposed by others. 

Individuals who are relatives of the members of the city teams (see members in the profile of each city) or of the Multi City Challenge team are excluded from participating in the challenge. 

HOW TO PARTICIPATE

Participation is divided in two steps:

  • Step 1 (November 4th - Extended until December 23rd): Posting an idea to address one of the above three challenges in a city (maximum one idea per challenge per participant) to africa.multicitychallenge.org. 
  • Step 2 (November 14th - December 23rd): Evaluating the ideas that you consider most 1) impactful, and 2) practical. 

Step 1: HOW TO UPLOAD AN IDEA (November 4th - Extended until December 23rd)

Go to https://africa.multicitychallenge.org and choose the challenge in which you wish to participate. The three challenges are reducing waste generation and improving waste management, building urban resilience in slums and informal settlements, and integrating the informal economy. Click the “Participate Now” button and register online as a new user by clicking the login button. (Watch demo video here).

Click on "Add a new idea" and complete the following fields:

  • Title of your idea (60 characters)
  • Description of your idea (2000 characters)
  • What problem does it solve?  (2000 characters)
  • What is the anticipated impact? (2000 characters)
  • If you are sharing this idea on behalf of an organisation, please indicate the name of the organisation (300 characters)
  • Upload an attachment with more information or data to support your proposal (optional)
  • Upload an image to describe your idea, video -60 seconds- or speech -60 seconds- (optional)
  • Click “Create” to submit your idea. You will not be able to modify your idea once it has been submitted.

The period for submission of ideas will be Wednesday November 4th - Extended until December 23rd.

By submitting your proposal, you agree to these general Terms and Conditions of the challenge and accept that your idea will be published on the project website.

Comment on the ideas by answering these questions (watch demo video here):

  • Why do you think this idea is impactful and/or practical?
  • Do you think this idea can be improved? If so, how?
  • You can answer these questions adding text (300 characters), a video  (60 seconds) or a speech (60 seconds)

Participate now!

Improving waste management Building urban resilience Integrating the informal economy

Step 2: HOW TO RATE AND RANK IDEAS (December 14th - December 23rd)

If you haven't already created an account, go to https://africa.multicitychallenge.org and choose the challenge in which you wish to participate. The three challenges are reducing waste generation and improving waste management, building urban resilience in slums and informal settlements, and integrating the informal economy). Click the “Participate Now” button and register online as a new user by clicking the login button (watch demo video here).

Rate the ideas using the two buttons provided:

  • Impact 🏆- On a scale of 1 to 5 (with 1 being the lowest and 5 being the highest) how important is this idea. With the right resources, is this idea, if implemented, likely to improve the problem?
  • Practicality ⏰- On a scale of 1 to 5 (with 1 being the lowest and 5 being the highest) how practical is this idea. With the right resources, can this idea be accomplished quickly?

The public rating and ranking will be open from Monday, December 14th until Wednesday, December 23rd, 2020.

SELECTION OF IDEAS: HOW THEY WILL BE EVALUATED

Evaluation process

How Will the Winners be Notified?

Winners will be notified by the Multi-City Challenge team via email during February 2021 and will be invited to participate in a virtual recognition ceremony.

CHALLENGE SCHEDULE

  • Launch:  November 4th, 2020
  • Submission of proposals: November 4th - extended until December 23rd  
  • Citizen vote on proposals: December 14th - December 23rd
  • Announcement of winners: February 2021
data.incentive: Winners will work with the city councils to develop their idea into a pilot and will receive a GovLab - New York University certificate.
data.winners_description: Below you can find all the winners of the Multi-City Challenge Africa 2020 in three categories. The winners have been selected by popular vote, independent expert evaluators and the participating cities. The Multi-City Challenge Winners were the proposals that were best evaluated across the board by our teams of experts and participating city councils. The City Winners were the favorite proposals of our participating city councils in the challenges they participated. Finally, some proposals received special recognitions for their exceptional innovativeness and forward-thinking, despite them not being among our select few winners.
